intro: Nepeta subincisa var. salangensis, commonly known as the Salangain catmint, is a perennial herb native to the mountainous regions of Central Asia. It is characterized by its slender, upright stems and small, tubular blue to purple flowers that bloom in late summer. The plant produces aromatic, fuzzy leaves that are often used in traditional medicine for their calming properties. It thrives in well-drained soil and full sun, making it a hardy addition to rock gardens or borders. Its unique appearance and fragrance make it a valuable ornamental and medicinal plant in its native habitat.
